title: Kathy Brown
text:
Kathy Brown (born July 12, 1960) is an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="Dance%20music">dance</a> and <a href="House%20music">house</a> <a href="Singing">singer</a> from <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>. Her credits include vocals on the songs "Turn Me Out (Turn to Sugar)" and "Strings of Life (Stronger on My Own)".
Musical career.
Brown began singing in her local <a href="gospel%20choir">gospel choir</a>. After joining the <a href="contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">contemporary R&B</a> group Sweet Cinnamon. Kathy met with New York-based producer David Shaw through a mutual friend. This collaboration led to her first single, "Can't Play Around", released in 1993 which was a number thirteen hit on the US "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Hot%20Dance%20Music/Club%20Play">Hot Dance Music/Club Play</a> <a href="record%20chart">chart</a>.
Brown scored number one success as the lead singer of Praxis, a musical project assembled by <a href="Record%20producer">producer</a>s <a href="Cevin%20Fisher">Cevin Fisher</a> and David Shaw. Praxis's "Turn Me Out", first released in 1994, has been <a href="remix">remix</a>ed and re-released several times since, with two subsequent US "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Hot%20Dance%20Music/Club%20Play">Hot Dance Music/Club Play</a> chart entries, including 1997's "Turn Me Out (Turn To Sugar)", which hit number one. "Turn Me Out" returned to the dance chart in 2003 with new <a href="remix">remix</a>es, this time climbing to #42. Brown collaborated with <a href="David%20Morales">David Morales</a> on 1999's "Joy" which climbed to number four on the Hot Dance Music/Club Play chart.
In 2004, Brown was the lead vocalist on British act <a href="Soul%20Central">Soul Central</a>'s "Strings of Life (Stronger on My Own)" which reached number six on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> and number one on the <a href="UK%20Dance%20Chart">UK Dance Chart</a>. The single was also a hit in <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, reaching number twenty-eight on the <a href="Eurochart%20Hot%20100%20Singles">Eurochart</a>. "Strings of Life" samples <a href="Derrick%20May%20%28musician%29">Is</a>'s 1989 <a href="Strings%20of%20Life">house classic of the same name</a>.
Brown's vocals animate other cuts such as "Voodoo Magic" and "Time & Time Again" with the Major Boys. Brown's rendition of "<a href="You%20Give%20Good%20Love">You Give Good Love</a>" reached the Top 10 of the <a href="UK%20Dance%20Chart">UK Dance Chart</a> in August 2002. In the spring 2006 she recorded "Get Another Love", released on <a href="Defected%20Records">Defected Records</a>. The track went on to score in the Top 10 of the <a href="BBC%20Radio%201">BBC Radio 1</a> Dance Chart.
In 2008, Brown and dance outfit White Knights released "Sound of the City". The single, written by <a href="Jason%20Gardiner">Jason Gardiner</a> and Nick Tcherniak about <a href="Soho">Soho</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, peaked at number six on the UK Upfront Club chart.
In the fall of 2010, Brown reconnected with producer David Shaw and partner Deep Influence to produce two tracks; "Feel the Music" and "Love and Pain" on the duo's digitally distributed Kontinuous Music.
